intro: Grastidium erectum, commonly known as the upright grass-tongue plant, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It features a rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, providing some drought resistance. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters, typically during the cooler months. Its root system is fibrous and shallow, allowing it to absorb moisture efficiently from the soil. Grastidium erectum is well adapted to harsh environments and is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements.
